content:
Posted: March 31, 2012
												Not a bad puzzle/action game.  Basically you move/shoot to color the balls/lines to control more land & spit out more abilities than the enemy.  The game is very basic and also very short.  I beat both episodes in about 2.5 hours.Each level has different goal, kill the enemy, capture ground, get certain colors, or live X amount of time.Overall, its ok for what it is.  If you like simple action puzzle games, might be your cup of tea!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												The second most played game in my collection - so a short review.First: This game is really fun!Second: It probably looks ugly and is most likely not well announced in its description: This is no mathematical puzzle-game! It is an action based game where you need awareness. Well, it would help you if you knew how to arrange colours quickly (and you might get more into it by time) - but you will in most cases simply not have the time to take it that way! I have to say that I never got a single achievement in this game - after over 60 hours of gameplay. I only used 'Quickstart' after completing a part of the beginners tutorial. And the fun I get out of this is fun for hours and hours. I do not wish to play campaigns here. I just wish to enjoy the fun of a quick play.If you do not pay attention you will play a close and hard match and suffer from earlier made mistakes. If you do pay attention enough you will win. Sometimes very fast! The next Quickstart of the game is near though…In my personal view this game is badly announced, not stimulating presented (except its simple TRON-like style) - and completely underrated. It is good enough to play it… a lot!

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Vertex Dispenser is a game with a huge learning curve. It's deceptive in that it has the asthetics of a casual game but the gameplay of chess. If you love logic puzzles and playing relaxing games before bed, Vertex Dispenser is recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A deceptively simple and graphically minimal game with chill electronic music, Vertex Dispenser is both fun and challenging - offering one part problem solving and one part competitive strategy. We greatly enjoyed the multiplayer vs. A.I. more than anything, though.The main shortcoming is the extreme minimalism.  The game could do with a bit of polish in its UI and graphics.  Simple doesn't have to mean sloppy. Nevertheless, one of my favorites in the genre since the first Hexxagon.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I usually tell my friends that I like smart, innovative games.  Now I realize I was wrong.I commend the creator for doing something very different, and not trying to dumb down the mechanics.  I am also completely overwhelmed by the sheer number of different abilities all mapped to separate keys and the boggling amount of information changing at an inhumanly quick pace.  I feel like super advanced AI would love playing this game, but I am a mere human.

Posted: September 1, 2012
												This is a mean ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a game, although maybe it's just my horrible lack of skill at RTSes. I want to describe it sort of as a puzzle-RTS? The only 'resources' are the color of points you control, allowing abilities to recharge faster the more of X color node you have. Try the demo? I straight up can't give a good confirm/deny if you'd like this one with ease like some other things. This is a competent little title that I just blow goats at.
